item.title: SVCDE Week 1
item.description: SVCDE Week 1 – Vectors & Vector Functions 1.1 Basic properties The magnitude of a vector $\vec{x} = \Vector{x_1 \\ x_2 \\ .. \\ x_n} \in \mathbb{R}^n$ is $$|\vec{x}| = \sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^n x_k^2}$$ Geometrically, this represents the distance to the vector’s tip from the origin and follows from generalised Pythagoras'. The unit vector $\hat{x}$ is the vector pointing in the direction of $\vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n$ of magnitude 1. So, $$\hat{x} = \frac{1}{|\vec{x}|}\vec{x}.

item.title: Assessment
item.description: Foundations of Data Science Essential assessment details 100% coursework 2 major courseworks worth 20% each, split 1-1 over the two semesters 2 class tests worth 10% each, at the end of each semester 1 huge project worth 40% in the second half of semester 2

item.title: Assessment
item.description: Introduction to Algorithms and Data Structures Essential assessment details 60% exam two parts: Part A. 5 compulsory questions worth 10 marks each Part B. choice of 2/3 questions worth 25 marks each semester 2 diet (April/May) 40% coursework 3 major courseworks worth 10% each, split 1-2 over the two semesters 6 multiple-choice quizzes worth 2% each 1 5-day window to complete them; time limit of one hour 3 per semester instant feedback First one is for practice and does not count.

item.title: Assessment
item.description: Probability Essential assessment details 100% coursework 4 hand-ins worth 20% (one hand-in every two weeks) 1 5 online quizzes worth 30% (one quiz every two weeks) 2 10 annotations worth 10% (one annotation per week) 1 final quiz worth 40% Starting week 4. ↩︎ Starting week 3. ↩︎

item.title: Assessment
item.description: Several Variable Calculus and Differential Equations Essential assessment details 60% exam online, open-book, 2 hours long end of semester 1 40% coursework 10 online quizzes worth 25% (one quiz per week) 1 10 hand-ins worth 15% (one hand-in per week) 1 9 best count. ↩︎

item.title: LFSRs
item.description: First, a primer The LFSRs (Linear Feedback Shift Registers) represent a family of very low-level, simple to implement, and darn quick ways of generating seemingly random sequences of bits. It is no surprise then that they are often used as PRNGs (pseudo-random number generators). In spite of their many aforementioned practical qualities they are, however, definitely not well known for their cryptographic strength. But let’s take things one at a time.

item.title: Computing discrete logs over GF(2 ^ n) in practice
item.description: Quick how-to # sage K.<x> = GF(2 ** n, impl='pari_ffelt') # invoke pari via SageMath's bindings g = K(x ** 4 + x ** 2 + 1) h = g ** 123 h.log(g) # => 123 The exact implementation SageMath uses for .log() with pari_ffelt can be found here. Even for a (relatively) large $n$ this seems to be instantaneous, as opposed to the default implementation which simply hangs. Other things to note Performing this calculation directly (in PARI/GP), e.
